item.title: Oil Holds Sharp Declines After China PMI Data
item.description: Oil prices fell 0.2% in Europe after weak Chinese economic data, and markets are worried the country’s commodity demand is weakening more quickly than anticipated, Commonwealth Bank said.

item.title: Bank of Thailand Raises Rate to Tame Inflation
item.description: Thailand’s central bank increased its policy rate by 25 basis points to 2.00% as it continued its efforts to tame inflation.

item.title: Base Metals Lower as Weak China Demand Weighs on Prices
item.description: Industrial metal prices were weaker with China’s disappointing economic recovery continuing to weigh on the demand outlook, according to ANZ.

item.title: Dollar Rises on Fed Rate Expectations, Weak Equities
item.description: The dollar was higher in European trading due to growing expectations the Fed will continue raising rates and falls in equity markets which increase demand for safe havens, UniCredit Research said.

item.title: French Inflation Eases
item.description: France’s consumer price index rose by 5.1% on year in May, a lower than expected print, helped by falling energy, food and services prices.

item.title: Handelsbanken Secures Deal to Sell Bulk of Finnish Business
item.description: Handelsbanken has agreed to sell parts of its Finnish operations to S-Bank, Oma Savings Bank and Fennia Life Insurance for around €1.3 billion.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 1.4%, Dragged by Trading Houses, Steelmakers
item.description: The Nikkei closed down 1.4%, dragged by declines in trading houses and steelmakers, as profit-taking kicked in on continued uncertainty over the inflation and economic outlook.

item.title: Slowdown in Inflation Set to Drive Eurozone Bond Yields Lower
item.description: The inflation-driven rally in eurozone rates markets looks set to continue with national CPI data likely to slow markedly, Commerzbank said.

item.title: China's Recovery Slows Further as Factory, Services Activity Pulls Back
item.description: China’s factory activity contracted for a second straight month while growth in the services sector slowed.

item.title: Boeing 737 MAX Victims' Families Can Seek Compensation for Pain and Suffering, Judge Rules
item.description: The aircraft maker has admitted responsibility for the 2019 crash, but has contested factoring victims’ precrash pain and suffering into damages.

item.title: Another Shoot-'em-Up Memorial Day Weekend in Chicago
item.description: The city’s new mayor attributes shootings to the ‘trauma’ of disinvestment.

item.title: Where Is the U.S. Economy Headed? Follow the Money
item.description: Debt markets, where lenders funnel money to businesses and consumers, are showing signs of strain.

item.title: The Turkish lira fell to a low amid concerns that Erdogan would stick to his unusual approach to managing the country's finances.
item.description: The Turkish lira fell to a low amid concerns that Erdogan would stick to his unusual approach to managing the country’s finances.

item.title: The Justice Department said it would drop some of the criminal charges against FTX's founder if the Bahamas says they violate the terms of his extradition to the U.S.
item.description: The Justice Department said it would drop some of the criminal charges against FTX’s founder if the Bahamas says they violate the terms of his extradition to the U.S.

item.title: Tech executives and artificial-intelligence scientists sounded the alarm about AI, saying in a joint statement that the technology poses an extinction risk as great as pandemics and nuclear war.
item.description: Tech executives and artificial-intelligence scientists sounded the alarm about AI, saying in a joint statement that the technology poses an extinction risk as great as pandemics and nuclear war.

item.title: Executives and early investors in companies that went public via SPACs sold shares worth $22 billion through well-timed trades, profiting before share prices collapsed.
item.description: Executives and early investors in companies that went public via SPACs sold shares worth $22 billion through well-timed trades, profiting before share prices collapsed.

item.title: A judge ruled that relatives of people who died in a 2019 Boeing 737 MAX crash can seek compensation for the victims' pain and suffering before the jet slammed into the ground in Ethiopia.
item.description: A judge ruled that relatives of people who died in a 2019 Boeing 737 MAX crash can seek compensation for the victims’ pain and suffering before the jet slammed into the ground in Ethiopia.

item.title: Noncompete clauses violate the federal law that governs union organizing and workers' rights to collective action, according to a memo released by the NLRB's top lawyer.
item.description: Noncompete clauses violate the federal law that governs union organizing and workers’ rights to collective action, according to a memo released by the NLRB’s top lawyer.

item.title: Ukraine and its allies are planning a summit of global leaders that would exclude Russia, aimed at garnering support for Kyiv's terms for ending the war, a Ukrainian presidential adviser and European diplomats said.
item.description: Ukraine and its allies are planning a summit of global leaders that would exclude Russia, aimed at garnering support for Kyiv’s terms for ending the war, a Ukrainian presidential adviser and European diplomats said.

item.title: House Republican leaders projected confidence that the debt-ceiling deal struck with President Biden would draw enough support to pass, while some conservative lawmakers angrily denounced the agreement.
item.description: House Republican leaders projected confidence that the debt-ceiling deal struck with President Biden would draw enough support to pass, while some conservative lawmakers angrily denounced the agreement.
